Drew,
Thank you!

I chose Mr. Bookland book just because of its easy and si=
mple codes, but I am working in the area of =C2=A0"Games", and I think Book=
land implementation is =C2=A0not a proper choice.
=C2=A0I want to implement=
 my project with =C2=A0a Visual Programming language, maybe "C#"!, but As I=
 said I do not have enough experience in C# and I could not understand some=
 of C# codes of NEAT implementation. So I need a simple example.

Adele


_=
_______________________________
 From: Drew Kirkpatrick <drew.kirkpatrick@g=
mail.com>
To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
Sent: Tuesday, December 6, 2011 6:22 PM=

Subject: Re: [neat] NEAT for beginners
 

=C2=A0 
Adele,

I also started o=
ff from Mat Buckland's book, and have been working with a modified version =
of his implementation. If you're particular about sticking with his impleme=
ntation and C++ (his is a relatively simple implementation of NEAT from wha=
t I understand) I can send you my code if you want (buggy work in progress)=
.=C2=A0

It's not a simple example at all (competitive coevolution), but it=
 would give you some code examples and bug fixes to Mat Buckland's original=
 implementation (mine is a Linux port). Probably only useful to you for loo=
king at the changes I made to Mr. Buckland's code, but that would be easy a=
s most of the code is the same, and the classes retained their names from t=
hose described in his book.=C2=A0

You might want to start with getting his=
 minesweeper (was that it?) example application running, and try putting in=
 some of the bug fixes folks have recommended in his implementation (I thin=
k I can help find those). Once you have that working, you might want to try=
 the XOR test, and perhaps pole balancing. I believe those are common tasks=
 to undertake.=C2=A0

Let me know if you want any code, or have any questio=
ns I might be able to help with. I'm afraid I'm far from a NEAT guru, but I=
 don't think too many folks are working with Mat Buckland's implementation =
now. I think that's a great book, and that chapter helped me considerably i=
n getting started working with NEAT.=C2=A0


-Drew


On Tue, Dec 6, 2011 at=
 2:01 AM, adeleh ebrahimi <adlh_ebrahimi@...> wrote:

 
>=C2=A0 
>Hi =
everybody
>I am new in learning NEAT. I studied Mr. Stanley paper, =C2=A0ti=
tled "evolving Neural Networks through Augmenting Topologies" and=C2=A0
>No=
w, I am studying last chapter of Mr. Buckland book - "AI techniques for Gam=
e Programming".
>
>
>But I need to know more about NEAT implementation with=
 an example. Is it possible to introduce me a proper and simple example wit=
h its tutorial. Unfortunately I don`t have enough experience in C#.=C2=A0
>=

>
>Sincerely
>Adele

</div><div>I also started off from Mat Buckland's book, and have been worki=
ng with a modified version of his implementation. If you're particular abou=
t sticking with his implementation and C++ (his is a relatively simple impl=
ementation of NEAT from what I understand) I can send you my code if you wa=
nt (buggy work in progress). </div>

<div><br></div><div>It's not a si=
mple example at all (competitive coevolution), but it would give you some c=
ode examples and bug fixes to Mat Buckland's original implementation (mine =
is a Linux port). Probably only useful to you for looking at the changes I =
made to Mr. Buckland's code, but that would be easy as most of the code is =
the same, and the classes retained their names from those described in his =
book. </div>

<div><br></div><div>You might want to start with getting=
 his minesweeper (was that it?) example application running, and try puttin=
g in some of the bug fixes folks have recommended in his implementation (I =
think I can help find those). Once you have that working, you might want to=
 try the XOR test, and perhaps pole balancing. I believe those are common t=
asks to undertake. </div>

<div><br></div><div>Let me know if you want=
 any code, or have any questions I might be able to help with. I'm afraid I=
'm far from a NEAT guru, but I don't think too many folks are working with =
Mat Buckland's implementation now. I think that's a great book, and that ch=
apter helped me considerably in getting started working with NEAT. </d=
iv>
